result.execSummary:
The defendant Carlos D. Jones was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Defendant shall not consume alcohol or other intoxicants.  Defendant must maintain absolute sobriety.
Defendant shall undergo an AODA Assessment and follow through with any recommendations resulting therefrom.

timeConds.notes:
Shall serve 20 days DCJ w/h&t commencing on/before 6/10/15
Consecutive to: with work release and transfer privileges

14CF157 & 14CF357 - Defendant Carlos D. Jones in court with attorney Steven J. Luchsinger.  James T. Sempf appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court finds state is victim rights compliant.  Court questions def and reviews chgs and pens.  NC plea entered in the Domestic Battery charge of 14CF157 & NC plea entered in count 1 of 14CF357.  Court accepts pleas and finds def guilty, remaining counts are DRI.  Victim makes stmt.  State makes sentencing recomendations.  Atty Luchsinger responds.  Victim makes additional stmt.  Def makes stmt.  Court heard and imposes sentence as follows:

14CF157:
w/h sentence - 2 years probation
20 days DCJ w/h&t comm on or before 6/10/15
AODA
maintain absolute sobriety
costs including DNA surcharge
reimburse Dodge County for court appointed attorney

14CF357:
w/h sentence - 2 yrs probation
60 days DCJ w/h&t - STAYED as COP
AODA
maintain absolute sobriety
court costs including surcharge
reimburse Dodge County for court appointed attorney

records.addlTxt: Defendant, Carlos D. Jones in court, James T Sempf appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court reviews petition and questions defendant; Court will appoint Atty Steve Luchsinger; Court sets payment plan at $50/mo commencing 7/15/14

Defendant shall not have any direct or indirect contact or communication with LFR, dob 4/14/79, JMR, dob 6/27/83 or JRR, dob 6/17/82 or their residence(s), except Defendant may go to the residence at issue one time in the company of a uniformed law enforcement officer to retrieve his/her personal property.  Defendant shall not have any violent or abusive contact with anyone.  Defendant shall not consume alcohol or other intoxicants.  Defendant must maintain absolute sobriety  and shall not go upon the premises of any establishment whose primary business activity involves the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, including bars, taverns, liquor stores and beer tents.

(1:14) Defendant Carlos D. Jones in custody via video with attorney Greg E Vollan (jail only).  Kurt F Klomberg appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant has received copy of Criminal Complaint and advised of rights, charges, penalties and right to Preliminary Hearing. Court finds probable cause. Prelim requested waiving time limits. Prelim set 7/10/14 @ 8:30am in Br. 1 & Review set 6/25/14 at 8:15am in Br. 4; Court sets bond at $1,000.00 PA BOND  with conditions:  Defendant shall not have any direct or indirect contact or communication with LFR, dob 4/14/79, JMR, dob 6/27/83 or JRR, dob 6/17/82 or their residence(s), except Defendant may go to the residence at issue one time in the company of a uniformed law enforcement officer to retrieve his/her personal property.  Defendant shall not have any violent or abusive contact with anyone.  Defendant shall not consume alcohol or other intoxicants.  Defendant must maintain absolute sobriety  and shall not go upon the premises of any establishment whose primary business activity involves the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, including bars, taverns, liquor stores and beer tents.
